titleStmt.title: A Guide to the United States’ History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Chad
Chad

sourceDesc.p: Researched and written by Christopher Morrison, February 2009

div.head: Summary
div.p: The United States recognized the Republic of Chad on August 11, 1960, in a congratulatory message from President Dwight D. Eisenhower to Prime Minister Tombalbaye.

div.head: U.S. Recognition of Chad’s Independence, 1960.
div.p: The United States recognized the Republic of Chad on August 11, 1960, in a congratulatory message from President Dwight D. Eisenhower to Prime Minister Tombalbaye. On that date, Chad’s independence from French Equatorial Africa was proclaimed.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations, 1960.
div.p: Diplomatic relations were established on August 11, 1960, when the American Consul at Brazzaville, Alan W. Lukens, presented his credentials as Charge d’Affaires.

div.head: Establishment of the American Embassy in Chad, 1961.
div.p: Embassy Fort Lamy (now N'Djamena) was established on February 1, 1961, with Frederic L. Chapin as Chargé d'Affaires ad interim.

div.head: American Embassy Closed, 1980.
div.p: The Embassy in N'Djamena was closed on March 24, 1980, when American diplomatic personnel were evacuated following the outbreak of heavy fighting in the city.

div.head: American Embassy Reopened, 1982.
div.p: The Embassy in N'Djamena was reopened on January 15, 1982, with John Blane as Principal Officer and Chargé d'Affaires ad interim.
